subject: RE: [junit] Making a large set of tests as efficient as possible
msgSnippet: We currently run JUnit with 1000 unittests with no outofMemory exceptions being thrown. There s no limit within JUnit that could cause your problem. I suspect
messageBody:
We currently run JUnit with 1000 unittests with no outofMemory exceptions
being thrown.

There's no limit within JUnit that could cause your problem. I suspect that
there is some form of resource hogging occurring within your code (either
test code, production code, or both) that is the real cause of the problem.

The setUp() & tearDown() methods that JUnit calls before & after each
testcase (method) is called, should be used where necessary to release
resources. This will allow the GarbageCollector to free memory as needed,
without you having to change the JVM's heap size.

HTH

Andrew

> objects to add these tests to a suite. I would like to know any best
> practices to ensure I don't get any OutOfMemoryErrors. I changed the
> jvm tag to increase virtual memory to say 512 but, if I keep adding
> many tests to this suite, what would be the next item to ensure I'm
> doing. I am also setting TestCase member variables to null where
> possible. What would be the next step? The reason I ask is because I
> would like to push JUnit to the limit and have it test all day and
> night for a large application. Any help or comments would be
> appreciated. Even different design techniques are welcome.
